title: Problem Overview
content:
This header documents Erdős Problem #143, which asks about the sparseness of sets that avoid being close to integer multiples of each other. The problem was partially solved in 2025 by Koukoulopoulos, Lamzouri, and Lichtman.

The $500 prize remains partially unclaimed - the strongest conjectures are still open!
mathContext: The condition |kx - y| ≥ 1 for all k ≥ 1 and distinct x, y means no element can be within distance 1 of any positive integer multiple of another element.

title: Well-Separated Sets
content:
A set is **well-separated under integer dilation** if for any two distinct elements x and y, and any positive integer k, the distance |kx - y| is at least 1.

This definition captures a strong separation property: not only are elements far from each other, but their integer multiples are also far from other elements.
mathContext:
Formally: A ⊆ (1, ∞), A is infinite and countable, and ∀ x ≠ y ∈ A, ∀ k ≥ 1: |kx - y| ≥ 1.

This generalizes the notion of primitive sets from integers to reals.

title: Counting Function
content:
The counting function counts how many elements of A lie in the interval [1, x]. This measures the "density" of A.

For sparse sets, the counting function grows slowly compared to x.
mathContext: countingFn(A, x) = |A ∩ [1, x]| using Set.ncard for the cardinality of possibly infinite intersections.

title: Conjecture (i): Lower Density Zero
content:
The **lower density** of A is the liminf of |A ∩ [1,x]|/x as x → ∞. If this is zero, there are arbitrarily long stretches where A is extremely sparse.

**Status**: OPEN. This is the strongest form of the conjecture.
mathContext: liminf_{x→∞} |A ∩ [1,x]|/x = 0 means: for any ε > 0, there are arbitrarily large x with |A ∩ [1,x]| < εx.

title: Conjecture (ii): Series Convergence
content:
Does the series ∑ 1/(x log x) converge when summed over A? This is a natural sparseness condition intermediate between (i) and (iii).

**Status**: OPEN. For integer primitive sets, Erdős proved this in 1935.
mathContext: The series ∑ 1/(n log n) over all integers diverges, but for sparse sets it may converge. The log x factor makes this stronger than asking about ∑ 1/x.

title: Conjecture (iii): Partial Sum Bound
content:
The partial reciprocal sum ∑_{x<n, x∈A} 1/x should be o(log n), meaning it grows slower than log n.

**Status**: SOLVED by Koukoulopoulos-Lamzouri-Lichtman (2025)!

This is the weakest of the three conjectures, but its proof was a major breakthrough.
mathContext: o(log n) means: for any ε > 0, eventually ∑_{x<n} 1/x < ε log n. Compare to the harmonic series where ∑_{k<n} 1/k ~ log n.

title: KLL Theorem (2025)
content:
The **Koukoulopoulos-Lamzouri-Lichtman Theorem** is the main result: for any well-separated set A, the partial sum ∑_{x<n, x∈A} 1/x = o(log n).

This is axiomatized because the proof uses advanced techniques from multiplicative number theory and GCD graphs that aren't yet in Mathlib.
mathContext: The proof constructs a GCD graph where vertices are elements of A and edges connect elements whose GCD-like interactions are bounded. Graph-theoretic arguments then show the sum cannot grow too fast.

title: The Partial Resolution
content:
This theorem directly applies the KLL result: if A is well-separated, then Conjecture (iii) holds.

The proof is immediate from the axiom - the mathematical heavy lifting is in KLL's paper.
mathContext: erdos_143_partial : WellSeparatedSet A → Conjecture_iii A follows directly from kll_theorem.

title: Connection to Primitive Sets
content:
A set of positive integers is **primitive** if no element divides another. For integers, well-separation implies primitivity!

If a divides b with b = ka, then |ka - b| = 0 < 1, violating well-separation. This connects the real problem to classical number theory.
mathContext:
IsPrimitiveSet A := ∀ a b ∈ A, a ≠ b → ¬(a | b).

Primitive sets were studied by Erdős, Behrend, and others in the 1930s.

title: Erdős 1935: Primitive Sets
content:
Erdős's 1935 result was the original motivation: for **integer** primitive sets, the series ∑ 1/(n log n) converges.

The open question is whether this extends to real well-separated sets - Conjecture (ii).
mathContext: For primitive A ⊆ ℕ, Summable (λ n, 1/(n log n)) over n ∈ A. This was proven using elementary number theory.
